awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Proposal:  Gatekeeping Communities:  The Role of Landlords in Neighborhood Change and Gentrification
awd_abstract_narration:
During the last few decades there has been an increase in gentrification in urban areas in the United States, as well as increasing economic inequality. In addition, there is not enough affordable housing to meet demand. The Great Recession exacerbated this problem, tightening an already constrained housing market for renters.  Landlords play a significant role in providing or prohibiting access to housing as cities gentrify and rental housing markets become more challenging. This project studies how landlords operate under these conditions. The project addresses the following research questions: How do landlords make sense of their role in both residential and commercial contexts? In what ways do landlords amplify or counter neighborhood changes associated with gentrification? How do the actions or inactions of landlords affect access to neighborhoods for various social groups? Understanding how landlords make sense of and react to neighborhood changes associated with gentrification, and the impact of this on including or excluding various demographic groups, will allow for increased understanding of the factors that shape racial and economic residential segregation in the United States. Project findings will have implications for housing policies in the United States.  

Research on gentrification theorizes that landlords are part of the gentrification process, but few studies have provided empirical evidence to analyze these claims. The focus of most gentrification research has been on the experiences of residents (both new and long-time residents)while analyses of landlords in gentrifying neighborhoods have been sparse. This project will address this gap by analyzing how both residential and commercial landlords understand their roles in the context of neighborhood changes associated with gentrification.  The primary data for this project will come from 50 in-depth, semi-structured interviews with landlords and property managers in four gentrifying neighborhoods in a large northeastern U.S. city. The project will include property managers because they occupy a unique position as intermediaries between landlords and tenants in the rental housing relationship. In addition, in order to better understand the day-to-day activities of rental property maintenance and upkeep, the project incorporates ethnographic fieldwork as a means of triangulating the interview data. The ethnographic component of the research project involves performing the duties of a maintenance technician for a large rental real estate company. This project will contribute to scholarship by addressing the gap in research on landlords, analyzing whether landlords act as gatekeepers in both residential and commercial real estate transactions, and by utilizing a strategy of participant observation with landlords, allowing for firsthand observation of their investment, maintenance, and rental agreement practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Drawing on in-depth, semi-structured interviews with 71 landlords and property managers who own and operate rental units in the Philadelphia, PA region, this study analyzes how the experiences of being a landlord in Philadelphia shape how landlords interact with tenants and navigate evictions. The respondents include landlords who rent to a diverse population including low-income tenants, college students, middle-income professionals, Section 8 tenants, and commercial tenants.

We find that Philadelphia's implementation of tax policies which incentivize big development are negatively impacting many small-scale landlords. Landlords utilize varying approaches for coping with tax increases and other economic pressures, and for some small-scale landlords, the tax policies and heightened competition from big developers are pushing them to reevaluate their position among Philadelphia's housing providers and cash out. This alarming trend could exacerbate the lack of affordable housing options and adversely affect economically vulnerable tenants, as small-scale landlords are more likely to work with tenants who are struggling to pay rent than large-scale landlords are. We find that the perceived burdens associated with evictions often make evictions less desirable for small-scale landlords than finding ways to work with tenants to keep them in their homes, including developing payment plans to help tenants catch up on back rent, adjusting rental rates, accepting services in lieu of rent, and aiding in referrals to housing and social service programs. Some landlords employ a technique of paying tenants to vacate, a practice referred to as cash for keys, which is an informal, off-the-books eviction. Our findings suggest that off-the-books evictions are far more prevalent than has been measured in official eviction data; therefore, the prevalence of residential displacement is more severe than previously documented.

Much of current public discourse, scholarly attention, and social policy frame landlords as greedy capitalists who exploit tenants and accumulate vast wealth. We find that this caricature of landlords both misses the variation in landlords' trajectories, and also individualizes a structural problem. While it is simpler to place the blame for the eviction crisis and lack of affordable housing solely on landlords, it is not effective to do so and may be exacerbating the problem. Broader structural realities including lack of affordable housing, lack of living wages, and rising healthcare and living costs (to identify only a few) in the United States contribute to deep economic inequalities in this country, preventing many people from making ends meet. Yet, rather than support systems that buoy economically vulnerable individuals and robust social policies for systemic change, neoliberal ideology and policies have shifted the responsibility to the private sector, tasking landlords with being a solution to these social problems by providing housing. This is not working. If our social discourse and public policies are not thoughtful in recognizing the complex structural inequalities connected to the lack of affordable housing and simply view greedy landlords as the problem, our society will continue to face deep economic inequalities and our policies could have unintended consequences, making the problem of affordable housing and the eviction crisis even worse.

The dissemination of these findings, implications and broader impacts is underway. Thus far, we have published a peer-reviewed journal article in Housing Policy Debate and presented at nine scholarly conferences, including at the American Sociological Association, Eastern Sociological Society, and Urban Affairs Association annual meetings. We have another article under peer-review and we are currently in the process of developing a book manuscript focusing on how landlords' backgrounds, life experiences, identities, and goals shape how they think about evictions. Throughout this study, we involved undergraduate students at our teaching-focused institutions, one of which is an HBCU. The research experience that students gained through this study equipped them for successful careers, and we plan to continue involving students in the next phases of disseminating the study findings.
